content.content: 1. (1) In this Regulation, “rural” means, (a) a municipality not described in the definition of “urban”, (b) territory without municipal organization, (c) a polling division designated as “rural” under subsection (2); “urban” means, (a) a city, town, village or improvement district having a population of at least 5,000, (b) a township having a population of at least 10,000, (c) a municipality adjacent to a city having a population of at least 100,000. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 1 (1). (2) The Chief Election Officer may, on the written recommendation of a returning officer, designate a polling division as rural. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 1 (2). (3) A designation of a polling division as rural remains in effect for all purposes during an election. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 1 (3).
content.raw_html:
1. (1) In this Regulation,

“rural” means,

(a) a municipality not described in the definition of “urban”,

(b) territory without municipal organization,

(c) a polling division designated as “rural” under subsection (2);

“urban” means,

(a) a city, town, village or improvement district having a population of at least 5,000,

(b) a township having a population of at least 10,000,

(c) a municipality adjacent to a city having a population of at least 100,000. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 1 (1).

(2) The Chief Election Officer may, on the written recommendation of a returning officer, designate a polling division as rural. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 1 (2).

(3) A designation of a polling division as rural remains in effect for all purposes during an election. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 1 (3).

content.content: 2. The fees and expenses allowed under the Act are set out in the Schedule. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 2.
content.raw_html: 2. The fees and expenses allowed under the Act are set out in the Schedule. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 2.

content.content: 3. The fees and allowable expenses prescribed in paragraphs 5 and 7 of the Schedule may be pro-rated downwards where the Chief Election Officer directs that the duties be done more than once between elections. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 3.
content.raw_html: 3. The fees and allowable expenses prescribed in paragraphs 5 and 7 of the Schedule may be pro-rated downwards where the Chief Election Officer directs that the duties be done more than once between elections. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 3.

content.content:
4. An amount not exceeding 30 per cent of any amount set out in the Schedule is prescribed as an additional amount payable where, in the opinion of the Chief Election Officer, by reason of the size and character of an electoral district or other special circumstances, an amount set out in the Schedule does not provide adequate remuneration to election officers or other persons employed at or with respect to an election, including landlords of premises used for the purpose of an election. R.R.O. 1990, Reg. 315, s. 4. SCHEDULE  Before and during an election


1.

Paid once for each official review and changes

 


 

Paid once during an election

$ .35


 

— other transportation and related travel expenses

4.30

Payment for any election expenses not specifically set out but necessary and reasonable for the proper conduct of an election

4.

170.00


 

Personal driving, each kilometre

.35

900.00

400.00


 

Typed descriptions, on 8½ by 14 inch white paper as per format supplied by the Chief Election Officer and including the production of carbon or machine copies required for distribution

490.00


6.

Storage of election supplies at home or elsewhere (no insurance required), per month

36.00


7.

Key — preparation of original or revised key to urban polling divisions, typed on 8 ½ by 14 inch white paper as per format supplied by the Chief Election Officer and including the production of carbon or machine copies sufficient for distribution, per original page

15.00


 

Plus — in an urban electoral district

550.00

minimum

120.00


 

maximum

550.00

305.00

Returning officer


9.

Personal fee

 


 

All duties including revision

3,425.00


 

Plus — Name fee — for each name on the polling list

 


 

If a poll is held (minimum $5,000)

.18


 

If no poll is held (minimum $2,500)

.08


10.

All duties connected with addressing, sorting by postal code and mailing notice of enumeration for each name enumerated

.12


Payment of office or other personnel

.20

Vouchers

3/5 of item 12

Personal driving as directed by the returning officer, each kilometre

.35


 

Related rural travel expenses as directed by the returning officer

.08

70.00

70.00

135.00

40.00

100.00

Film and metal plate (if required), up to $13 per page

 


 

When collated into complete sets in poll number sequence, up to $11 per poll

 


Proclamation


29.

Film and plates, if required, up to $14 each

 


Notice of enumeration card


30.

Printing two sides, black ink, on white bristol; as per specification set out by the Chief Election Officer

 


 

First 100 cards per poll, up to $19

 


 

Each additional 100 cards per poll, up to $3.25

 


Notice of poll


31.

As sample format — up to a maximum of 400 copies (English or French or both English and French), up to $105 the lot

 


 

Film and plate, if required, up to $14 each

 


Ballots


32.

Printing two sides, numbering once on perforated stub and stitched or stapled (no gumming) into pads of twenty-five ballots each —

 


 

set up cost, up to $745 the lot

 


 

Plus:

 


 

2 or 3 names per ballot, up to $27 per 1000

 


 

4 names per ballot, up to $38 per 1000

 


 

5 names per ballot, up to $40 per 1000

 


 

6 names per ballot, up to $45 per 1000

 


 

7 names per ballot, up to $48 per 1000

 


Sundry printing


33.

As ordered by the returning officer

Invoices
